moves.1. e4 c5 2. Na3: an original approach.  though white never did anything with the horse during the game it could have gone to c2 after c3 and went places from there.
moves.2... Nc6 3. Nf3 d6 4. Bc4 Nf6 5. d3 e6 6: Not 8 Bh4 Nxe4! 9 Bxe7 Nxd2 10 Bxd8 Nxf3+ 11 gxf3 Kxd8 or 9 dxe4 Bxh4 10 Nxh4 Qxh4 11 Qxd6 Qxe4+ 12 Kf1 Qd4! with an extra pawn
moves.8... O-O 9. e5: 9 c3 was probably the best try.  Weaker was 9 0-0-0 a6 10 c3 b5 11 Bb3 b4 12 cxb4 cxb4 13 Nc4 a5 with the threat of ... a4
moves.9... dxe5 10. Bxe5: this hands black the two bishops but 10 Nxe5 is well met by Na5 gaining the two bishops that way.
moves.10... Nxe5 11. Nxe5 Nd5: 11 ... Qd4 is defended by 12 Qc3 so black decides to go with the text looking for active play.
moves.12. Bxd5: this is very bad judgement on white's part handing black the bishop pair vs. his two knights.
moves.12... Qxd5 13. Nf3 b6 14. O-O Bb7: the possible mate on g2 creates some nice tactical possibilities for black.
moves.15. c4 Qc6 16. Nb5 a6 17. Nc3 Rad8 18. a: here black can not be too aggressive.  18 ... Rd4 is ably met by 19 Ne4!
moves.20... Bf6: the trap was 20 ... Rxd3? 21 Nd5! exd5 22 Ne5 or 21 ... Qd6 22 Ne5!
moves.21. Rab1: one might wonder if this was a mouse slip since 21 Rac1 was the logical defense to the knight.
moves.21... Bxc3 22. b4 Bf6: getting the bishop out of there and avoiding complications.
moves.23. b5 axb5 24. cxb5: one might have expected 24 Rxb5.  The energetic response for black is 24 ... Rxd3! for if 25 Rfb1 Rd1+ 26 Ne1 Qxg2 mate!
moves.24... Qd6: rather than 24 ... Qd5 playing for possible mates on g2 the text is all business
moves.25. Qe3 Qxd3 26. Rbd1: allowing an elegant finish but white should lose anyway a piece and a pawn down.
moves.26... Qxd1: the conclusion is 27 Rxd1 Rxd1+ 28 Ne1 R8d3! 29 Qe2 Bc3! with an easy win.
